raw_comment: From the graph, I noticed that the graph compares the frequency of communication between young men and young women with their parents. It looks at three modes of communication: sending texts, phone or video-chat, and visiting in person. Particularly, young women consistently communicate more frequently with their parents across all methods compared to young men. Texting is the most common method for both genders, with the largest gap in communication frequency observed here. The difference in frequency of in-person visits is the smallest, though it still shows that young women visit their parents more often than young men. I wonder why there is a noticeable difference in communication frequencies between genders. Are gender norms or upbringings influencing these patterns? Also, how might these patterns shift as people age beyond their 30s? What would the data look like if only considering those in their early twenties or college students? As a college student, my community is filled with mainly busy individuals and for many young adults, moving out from their parents' home marks a transition to more independence. However, the frequency of contact with parents can vary widely depending on individual circumstances like proximity, work schedules, and the nature of the parent-child relationship.
